title: Temporal and Operational Concepts - Market Entry, Purpose, Misuse

placing_on_market.definition: The first making available of an AI system or a general-purpose AI model on the Union market

critical_elements.element: AI system or GP AI model

placing_on_market.interpretation: Trigger moment for provider obligations - first commercial availability
placing_on_market.examples: First sale, first distribution, first supply for commercial activity

making_available_on_market.definition: The supply of an AI system or a general-purpose AI model for distribution or use on the Union market in the course of a commercial activity, whether in return for payment or free of charge

elements.element: AI system or GP AI model
In the course of a commercial activity
elements.flag: MEDIUM_CONFIDENCE: 'commercial activity' - does FOSS distribution count? Not-for-profit organizations? Academic distribution?

elements.element: Whether in return for payment or free of charge
elements.note: Payment not required - freemium, free trials, etc. all included

making_available_on_market.critical_interpretative_question: FOSS under Art 2(12) excluded unless high-risk/prohibited/transparency-obligated. Does FOSS distribution = 'commercial activity'? Likely NO for pure open source, but requires case-by-case evaluation.
making_available_on_market.broader_than: Placing on market - includes subsequent supply, not just first

putting_into_service.definition: The supply of an AI system for first use directly to the deployer or for own use in the Union for its intended purpose

alternative_scenarios.description: Supply for first use directly to deployer

putting_into_service.critical_distinction: Putting into service = operational deployment. Placing on market = commercial availability. Can occur simultaneously or sequentially.
examples: Company develops AI system and deploys internally (own use) = putting into service
Provider delivers and configures system for customer's use = putting into service
SaaS model: first offering = placing on market, first customer deployment = putting into service

intended_purpose.definition: The use for which an AI system is intended by the provider, including the specific context and conditions of use, as specified in the information supplied by the provider in the instructions for use, promotional or sales materials and statements, as well as in the technical documentation

elements.element: Use for which system is intended

elements.critical: PROVIDER defines intended purpose, not deployer

elements.element: Including specific context and conditions of use

determination_sources.description: Intended purpose determined from provider's documentation and communications

intended_purpose.critical_insight: Intended purpose is PROVIDER-DEFINED, not deployer-determined. Deployer using system differently = misuse (potentially 'reasonably foreseeable misuse' per 3(13)).
implications: Risk management (Art 9) scope defined by intended purpose
Misuse determination by comparison to intended purpose
Provider liability linked to intended purpose
interpretative_questions: What if provider's documented purposes are vague/broad?
Can provider disclaim liability by narrowly defining intended purpose?
Provider updates intended purpose post-market - substantial modification?
intended_purpose.flag: MEDIUM_CONFIDENCE on boundary cases: vague purposes, multi-purpose systems, purpose evolution

reasonably_foreseeable_misuse.definition: The use of an AI system in a way that is not in accordance with its intended purpose, but which may result from reasonably foreseeable human behaviour or interaction with other systems, including other AI systems

elements.element: NOT in accordance with intended purpose
May result from reasonably foreseeable human behaviour
elements.flag: LOW_CONFIDENCE: 'reasonably foreseeable' is highly context-dependent. What standard? What foresight expected of provider?

elements.element: OR may result from interaction with other systems

reasonably_foreseeable_misuse.critical_insight: Provider must consider and risk-manage MISUSE that is reasonably foreseeable, not just intended use (Art 9(2)(b)).

factors_likely_relevant: Known historical misuse of similar systems
standard_of_foreseeability.note: No explicit standard in Act - requires LLM evaluation with contextual factors

examples_hypothetical: Facial recognition sold for access control, used for emotion detection = potentially reasonably foreseeable
Medical diagnosis AI used for non-medical prediction = depends on context
Content moderation AI repurposed for surveillance = potentially reasonably foreseeable depending on capabilities
reasonably_foreseeable_misuse.obligations_triggered: Article 9(2)(b) requires risk estimation/evaluation under reasonably foreseeable misuse conditions

substantial_modification.definition: A change to an AI system after its placing on the market or putting into service which is not foreseen or planned in the initial conformity assessment carried out by the provider and as a result of which the compliance of the AI system with the requirements set out in Chapter III, Section 2 is affected or results in a modification to the intended purpose for which the AI system has been assessed

elements.element: After placing on market or putting into service
NOT foreseen or planned in initial conformity assessment
elements.flag: MEDIUM_CONFIDENCE: How specific must initial conformity assessment be regarding future changes?

triggering_results.description: Change is substantial if it results in EITHER consequence:

consequences.description: Compliance with Chapter III, Section 2 requirements is affected
consequences.flag: MEDIUM_CONFIDENCE: 'affected' - positive or negative? Material vs trivial?
consequences.note: Any impact on high-risk requirements = substantial

consequences.description: Modification to intended purpose for which system was assessed

substantial_modification.critical_legal_effect: Substantial modification may turn deployer into provider (assumes provider obligations)
interpretative_challenges: Continuous learning systems - when does adaptation = substantial modification?
Software updates - planned vs unplanned boundary
Parameter tuning by deployer - substantial or not?

critical_interrelationships.market_entry_sequence: Placing on market (first availability) → Making available on market (subsequent supply) → Putting into service (operational deployment)
critical_interrelationships.purpose_misuse_spectrum: Intended purpose (3(12)) → Reasonably foreseeable misuse (3(13)) → Unforeseeable misuse (not covered)
critical_interrelationships.modification_threshold: Planned updates (OK) → Substantial modification (3(23)) → Re-assessment required
critical_interrelationships.provider_deployer_shift: Substantial modification can convert deployer → provider for that system
